Authors: Fisch B.A.; Freund D.; Naor M.
Title: Secure physical computation using disposable circuits
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: Columbia University, United States; Cornell University, United States; Weizmann Institute of Science, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Fisch B.A., Columbia University, United States; Freund D., Cornell University, United States; Naor M., Weizmann Institute of Science, Israel
Abstract: In a secure physical computation, a set of parties each have physical inputs and jointly compute a function of their inputs in a way that reveals no information to any party except for the output of the function. Recent work in CRYPTO’14 presented examples of physical zero-knowledge proofs of physical properties, a special case of secure physical two-party computation in which one party has a physical input and the second party verifies a boolean function of that input. While the work suggested a general framework for modeling and analyzing physical zero-knowledge protocols, it did not provide a general theory of how to prove any physical property with zero-knowledge. This paper takes an orthogonal approach using disposable circuits (DC)—cheap hardware tokens that can be completely destroyed after a computation—an extension of the familiar tamper-proof token model. In the DC model, we demonstrate that two parties can compute any function of their physical inputs in a way that leaks at most 1 bit of additional information to either party. Moreover, our result generalizes to any multi-party physical computation. Formally, our protocols achieve unconditional UC-security with input-dependent abort. © International Association for Cryptologic Research 2015.
Index Keywords: Cryptography; Physical properties; Timing circuits; General theory; Hardware tokens; Presented examples; Tamper-proof tokens; Two-party computation; Zero knowledge; Zero knowledge proof; Zero-knowledge protocols; Boolean functions
